channel.title: The New Yorker — Reporting
channel.description: Latest reporting from The New Yorker

item.title: The Engines and Empires of New York City Gambling
item.description: As plans are laid for a new casino, one can trace, through four figures, a history of rivalry and excess, rife with collisions of character and crime.

item.title: ICE’s Spectacle of Intimidation
item.description: Immigrants showing up for court dates in Manhattan must now navigate past rows of masked federal agents.

item.title: How to Live Forever and Get Rich Doing It
item.description: As researchers work to make death optional, investors see a chance for huge returns. But has the human body already reached its limits?

item.title: How Much Is Trump Profiting Off the Presidency?
item.description: An honest accounting of our Executive-in-Chief’s runaway self-enrichment.

item.title: How an Ultra-Rare Disease Accelerates Aging
item.description: Teen-agers with progeria have effectively aged eight or nine decades. A cure could help change millions of lives—and shed light on why we grow old.

item.title: Is Mac DeMarco the Last Indie Rock Star?
item.description: The musician’s overwhelming popularity can overshadow his ethos of self-reliance. On his new album, “Guitar,” he played every instrument and is releasing it on his own label.

item.title: The Family Fallout of DNA Surprises
item.description: Through genetic testing, millions of Americans are estimated to have discovered that their parents aren’t who they thought. The news has upended relationships and created a community looking for answers.

item.title: Bill Belichick Goes Back to School
item.description: Can the legendary former Patriots coach transform U.N.C. football?

item.title: Pam Bondi’s Power Play
item.description: Donald Trump now has the Attorney General he always wanted—an ally willing to harness the law to enable his agenda.

item.title: The Otherworldly Ambitions of R. F. Kuang
item.description: The author of “Babel” and “Yellowface” is drawn to stories of striving. Her new fantasy novel, “Katabasis,” asks if graduate school is a kind of hell.
